To add to your thought, there are some additional barriers to convincing people that universal single payer healthcare would be good for them:

1. People don't like change. It's the "Devil You Know.." Syndrome.

2. People don't think the government is particularly efficient or trustworthy either--What if their healthcare experience ends up being like going to the DMV?
Single payer would drastically shrink if not do away with the private health insurance industry.  It has been a cash cow for them, but it is also their bread and butter.

All the commenters so far tonight favor single payer (as do I), but yet we never seem to get any closer to adopting such a system.  A chief reason is the power of the private health insurance industry itself, which will fight tooth and nail to avoid giving up such a cash cow.  Only when the people convince themselves that it is not un-American to have a sector of the economy that doesn't offer anybody a chance to make a buck will the system become reformable.  We need to understand that the virtues of capitalism notwithstanding, there are a few areas where the opportunity to make a profit is counterproductive.

Arthur Herbert Fonzarelli (also known as "Fonzie", "Fonz" or "The Fonz") is a fictional character played by Henry Winkler in the American sitcom Happy Days (1974–1984). He was originally a secondary character, but eventually became the lead. By the mid-1970s, he dwarfed the other characters in popularity.

Henry Winkler, who played The Fonz, was born in Manhattan, New York City, the son of Ilse Anna Maria (née Hadra) and Harry Irving Winkler, a lumber company president. Winkler's Jewish parents emigrated from Germany to the United States in 1939, "on the eve" of World War II.

Winkler attended the McBurney School, received his bachelor's degree from Emerson College in 1967, and earned his MFA from the Yale School of Drama in 1970. In 1978, Emerson gave Winkler an honorary doctorate of humane letters. Winkler has also received a Doctor of Humane Letters from Austin College

A heart attack and an allergic reaction usually present with completely different symptoms! I am so sorry this happened to you.

ERs are generally exceedingly busy and it invariably means spending several hours in great discomfort and in close proximity to people who have communicable ailments. That said, had you gone, the triage nurse might have told you what is wrong and your stay might have been a short one.

As for drugs and allergies, please let your pharmacist know you reacted to what you were prescribed. Should some other doctor prescribe a drug that is in the same family, chances are good that the pharmacy will point it out to her or you before filling the order. A resource I use to look up drugs and their side effects is www.rxlist.com

In my area, there are lots of urgent care clinics that are open 24 hours. The downside is that they employ lots of nurse practitioners and are generally staffed only by one MD. That might have been an additional option for you.

Having a child with special needs, one of my criteria for picking doctors is knowing all the doctors in the practice take turns being on-call. Unless there are complications and a long-standing relationship with that doctor, may I suggest you switch to someone who is more accommodating?

I hope you feel a whole lot better!

If you think that selling or eating unhealthy food affects only yourself you are wrong.  We all pay for unhealthy restaurants and living, whether insured or uninsured.  Insurance rates are based on actuarial tables; actuarial tables are built on probabilities of illness; probabilities of illness are based on estimates of what people eat and how well they take care of their health.  Actuaries are mathematicians who know that fat, sugar and salt are addictive and when offered to consumers in large quantities and on every street corner, health care costs rise and they therefore recommend to insurers that rates rise.  Doctors and hospitals base their rates on costs and revenues.  If they treat lots of obese, unhealthy and uninsured patients, the cost of an each individual service goes up, way up.  We all subsidize Five Guys Burgers and Fries for selling killing foods to the insured and uninsured alike.

Thank you for your great observation about the aromas here. We just returned from two weeks out of state, and the minute we approached the lagoon which forms the southern border of our town, I knew that we were home in coastal SoCal just by the unique salty/spicy scent of the air around the lagoon.

When we hike, which we do all over the state, I'm constantly picking at the plants and rubbing the leaves in my hands (don't worry, I know what poison oak looks like). Home is a mix of coastal buckwheat, laurel and cleveland sage. The eastern sierra in the summer is the smell of approaching rain on dust. The Central valley is cut grass, mixed with over-ripe tomatoes and burning rice straw. As a kid, I could close my eyes and know when we were driving through Mission Viejo because of the intoxicating smell of orange blossoms (sadly, that's no longer true in Orange County, but there are still plenty of citrus groves elsewhere throughout the state).

I'm an SF native, but raised in both parts of the state, and currently reside in San Diego. I love it all: north, south, inland and coastal California. I've lived and worked around the country and even in other places in the world. Nothing else compares.

4) Vast government sector, employing 80% of the locals, consuming vast resources. Singapore's debt to GDP ratio is 100%, inflation is 6%. All construction work by foreign workers, making 500 $ a month. Foreign bus drivers went on strike recently (no union), were sent to prison, then back to China.
